column4: I just installed 'linux-image-686-smp' package for my Dual P3/600 box.. is it accurate that if I cat /proc/cpuinfo it only says '1' under Processors?
anyone have the clue on my dual proc question?
oh lord. grow up
I just installed 'linux-image-686-smp' package for my Dual P3/600 box.. is it accurate that if I cat /proc/cpuinfo it only says '1' under Processors?
after reboot, no
yeah, i did reboot.  if i display what kernel im running under, should it be appended by smp, like the package name?
it should be
okay, how can i display what kernel im running under? =)
that is mine. try uname -a
And it does detect both processors in bios and upon post.
any idea what i can check from here? or maybe a document to read up on this?
you should see two same stanzas in /proc/cpuinfo now
one for "processor 0" and one for "processor 1"

wow.. i feel like a idiot now.. its actually displaying both procs, first proc is Processor: 0, but when it display it, my window is sized perfectly so that i cannot even see 1 line from the first processors info output.
thanks for the help tho. =)
yw. many things start from 0 at unix and C
If you dont mind, one more real fast question.. whats the best cpu load monitoring tool for dual proc? is gdesklets suitable?
yeah, thats why i feel like an idiot as well.. i should have realized that fact.
:)). I personally dont trust eye candy apps. therefore I dont recommend gdesklets for monitoring. but you should try.
i just like a visual based graphs of current and previous loads.. and it provides that, so.. i dont know of a better one.  what cpu load monitor do you recommend?
